Package datastructures

Class List<T>

java.lang.Object
datastructures.List<T>
public class List<T>
extends java.lang.Object
This class represents a list data structure. This package was taken from "Java: How to Program, 11th Edition" (Deitel). This example can be found at textbook_examples_11th_edition.ch21.fig21_12.src.

  • Field Summary

    Fields 
    Modifier and Type Field Description
    private ListNode<T> firstNode
    This private ListNode object refers to the first node in the list.
    private ListNode<T> lastNode
    This private ListNode object refers to the last node in a list.
    private java.lang.String name
    This private String represents the name of the list; used for printing.

  • Constructor Summary

    Constructors 
    Constructor Description
    List()
    This is the first of two constructors in the List class.
    List​(java.lang.String listName)
    This is the second of two constructors in the List class.

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type Method Description
    void insertAtBack​(T insertItem)
    This method is responsible for inserting a new node at the back of the list with the data passed in.
    void insertAtFront​(T insertItem)
    This method is responsible for inserting a new node at the front of the list with the data passed in.
    boolean isEmpty()
    This method is responsible for determining whether this list is currently empty.
    void print()
    This method is responsible for printing out the contents of the List.
    T removeFromBack()
    This method is responsible for removing the last node from the end of the list.
    T removeFromFront()
    This method is responsible for removing the fist node from the front of the list.

    Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

    clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

  • Field Details

    • firstNode

      private ListNode<T> firstNode
      This private ListNode object refers to the first node in the list.

    • lastNode

      private ListNode<T> lastNode
      This private ListNode object refers to the last node in a list.

    • name

      private java.lang.String name
      This private String represents the name of the list; used for printing.

  • Constructor Details

    • List

      public List()
      This is the first of two constructors in the List class. It is a no-argument constructor which simply creates an empty list with "list" as the name. It does this by calling the one-argument constructor and passing it "list".

    • List

      public List​(java.lang.String listName)
      This is the second of two constructors in the List class. It takes in one String as an argument and uses it to create an empty list with the given name.
      Parameters:
      listName - This String is used to initialize the name of the List being created.

  • Method Details

    • insertAtFront

      public void insertAtFront​(T insertItem)
      This method is responsible for inserting a new node at the front of the list with the data passed in. If the list is empty, it simply creates a new node and assigns firstNode and lastNode to it. Otherwise, it creates a new node, passing in firstNode as the nextNode, and then assigns firstNode to the new node.
      Parameters:
      insertItem - This object of type T represents the data that will be contained in the new node.

    • insertAtBack

      public void insertAtBack​(T insertItem)
      This method is responsible for inserting a new node at the back of the list with the data passed in. If the list is empty, it simply creates a new node and assigns firstNode and lastNode to it. Otherwise, it creates a new node, (by calling the one-argument constructor, meaning the nextNode will be null), and assigns the new node to lastNode and lastNode's nextNode.
      Parameters:
      insertItem - This object of type T represents the data that will be contained in the new node.

    • removeFromFront

      public T removeFromFront() throws EmptyListException
      This method is responsible for removing the fist node from the front of the list. If the list is empty, it throws an EmptyListException, passing in the name of the list to the constructor. Otherwise it captures the data from the first node in a variable, then updates the firstNode to be firstNode's nextNode (or null if there is only one node in the list). It then returns the data of the removed node.
      Returns:
      This method returns an object of type T, representing the data of the node removed from the list.
      Throws:
      EmptyListException - This method throws an EmptyListException if the list is already empty.

    • removeFromBack

      public T removeFromBack() throws EmptyListException
      This method is responsible for removing the last node from the end of the list. If the list is empty, it throws an EmptyListException, passing in the name of the list to the constructor. Otherwise it captures the data from the last node in a variable, then updates the lastNode to be the node prior to lastNode (or null if there is only one node in the list). It then returns the data of the removed node.
      Returns:
      This method returns an object of type T, representing the data of the node removed from the list.
      Throws:
      EmptyListException - This method throws an EmptyListException if the list is already empty.

    • isEmpty

      public boolean isEmpty()
      This method is responsible for determining whether this list is currently empty. It does this by checking to see if the firstNode is null.
      Returns:
      This method returns a boolean value indicating whether the list is currently empty (true if it is).

    • print

      public void print()
      This method is responsible for printing out the contents of the List. If the list is empty, it prints out a message saying so. Otherwise, it prints out the data for each of the elements in the list.
